events.title: Goals of the company and how to achieve them
events.abstractText: At TOPdesk we have high level goals that are set to work towards becoming a well known player in the service management field worldwide. But what are those goals? Do you still remember? Are they even relevant for us within the development environment? If so, how can we make sure we work towards achieving those goals? In this session we will discuss what this means for us and how we can help reaching the target destination.

events.title: Alignment Between Departments
events.abstractText: Let's talk about alignment! There are cross-team topics in Development, that tend to fall off the table. In this session we will focus on when and how to collaborate with each other in order to avoide unneccesary/double work and optimise planning.

events.title: Moving from Developer to PM and Back again
events.abstractText:
In this presentation, I will share what I’ve experienced in that time. Expect answers to questions like:
  • What were you thinking when you volunteered?
  • Those Product Managers, are they any fun up close?
  • What about the transition bonus?
  • Does this now mean you have met actual customers? And do you really need to?
  • Have you gotten worse at programming?
  • Now that you’ve worked with other departments, is Development still your favorite?
  • Can I do it too?
You are also very much encouraged to mail me questions upfront. An “experienced committee” will then determine if and how your questions will become part of the presentation.

events.title: How do our department structures help reaching our goals?
events.abstractText:
The development department consists of a lot of different structures to help us reach our goals. Some of those structures are related to roles, like Product Management, Talent Leads and Architects. Other structures are based on expertise, like Accessibility, Databases or Security. And then there are the Scrum teams that are producing the product.

The total list of structures is much longer.

During this session, together we will try to answer the following questions:

- What do we expect from each of these structures to contribute to our goals?

- How can they be improved?

- What threats or problems prevent the structures from being successful?

- How can we solve those problems?

We will start with a recap of the long term development goals and review the list of existing structures. After that we'll split up into subgroups and divide the structures. Each subgroup will spend about 15 minutes on each question for all assigned structures.

We complete the session by sharing the highlights and insights we got during the breakout sessions from the subgroups.

events.title: A biologist's perspective to maintaining legacy code
events.abstractText:
Ever since Watson&Crick discovered the double helix, we know that DNA is nothing less than the source code of life. Genes are classes, Proteins are objects, and humans run on 4-billion year old legacy software. During evolution, life has encountered problems that are surprisingly similar to problems that programmers face.

What is the relation between the genetic code and computer code? What can fruit fly mutants tell us about modularity? What does a bee hive tell us about effectively developing microservices? What do antibiotic-resistant hospital bacteria tell us about how teams can share ideas? How does the theory of evolution help us design better software?

events.title: Can developers have more influence on development choices by using data?
events.abstractText:
Where to spend time on during development is a very difficult choice. I assume every developer (as every TOPdesk colleague) has some opinion on what to work on next. Improve performance, make the usability better, code maintainability, ….

Over the last years we've seen we are able to gather more data on our product in use. As developers we have an excellent skillset to make the right data available to make better choices. However, I like to argue that data can be used a lot more and better to help in making choices.

In this session I would like to explore if we indeed can use data better and more for making choices. What is needed to do this more?

events.title: Customers and their needs
events.abstractText: We all know the personas and their needs in our projects. But aren't you wondering how our customers really use our tool? What fun and creative ways they see to use your code (without bespoke work)? Who are these 4000 customers? Do we support all Dutch Ministries? Do we only handle tickets about printers and coffe machines? Join this accessible session and prepare yourself for some (inter)action!

events.title: What's your source of inspiration?
events.abstractText:
People work hard at TOPdesk, collaborate with many colleagues and need to pay attention to many things happening around them. It's a demanding job. This makes it important to have ways to recharge, generate fresh ideas and keep a high level of engagement & motivation. Sharing our experiences could definitively help, both to acknowledge that this is sometimes challenging and to learn from each other (cross-pollination).

Some examples of things that could be presented and/or discussed:

Learning new programming languages, frameworks & libraries, doing work outside your regular role [design/program/test, guide summer interns, attend a taster day or organise the IDM ;-)], going to conferences and meetups to get new ideas and meet & talk to new people, discovering what you are passionate about, listening to podcasts on topics that you find interesting, teaching people about things your passionate about, creative Apenkooi projects, etc.

events.title: How to improve TOPdesk's performance
events.abstractText:
Recently our software has often had performance problems, especially on SaaS. Sometimes SaaS environments are completely taken down and clients are unable to use TOPdesk. We at the Performance Guild want to take action to reduce these problems. And we need your help! We see that more and more development teams are making performance tests and creating performance metrics. We'd like to get together and see how we can share experience and tools among teams.

This session will start with a short introduction about our recent performance issues. We’ll continue with an interactive session where you can:

- share experience you and your team have with performance (testing, monitoring, troubleshooting)

- brainstorm about how we can better collaborate to deliver software that performs well, and about how the performance guild can help development teams

events.title: Anything you ever wanted to know about aspects of the architecture but never dared asking about
events.abstractText:
Let's talk about

Graceful degradation
Optimal size and number of services
Caching other services' data
Message busses as operational databases
Versioning

or anything else that pops up in your mind!

events.title: Service Infrastructure and smart cats
events.abstractText: This session is about how Alfonzo and Ops had to work together to get the Smartcat project successfully deployed in production. We think it is a prime example of devops in action and hope to get a discussion going on how to fine tune collaboration even further.

events.title: User Research at TOPdesk
events.abstractText: Over the past few months, we have been working together to understand the state of user research at TOPdesk, define the problems, and think of where we want to be. We have created measures of success that we will build on during this workshop. The goal of the workshop is to develop a roadmap for ourselves and begin to get practical about planning deliverables and structure for the future. If you have not been involved thus far, but would like to be involved, you are welcome to join, but will be asked to be an ongoing participant! PM/POs would especially be appreciated!

events.title: Guilds Poster Session
events.abstractText: Guilds with clear ties to development are present to share their story with you. Walk around, look at the posters, talk to guild members and vote for the best poster of the conference. Enjoy the content at your own pace.

events.title: Guilds & how they should work
events.abstractText:
Since a few years we have guilds in development. But do we use all the opportunities they can offer? How can we make them even better? Let's together create a vision of the improved guild concept we want and need, and create a roadmap of how to get there!

The session will start with a short overview of how guilds started out and a proposal for an experiment on how to improve. After a discussion and alignment and refinement of the proposal, we will work in small groups on what is needed to get there.

events.title: The Security TOP 5
events.abstractText: The OWASP Top 10 is awesome and it's great, but it also reflects the state of Security in the whole world rather than the current state at TOPdesk. That's why we present the TOPdesk Security Top 5. This lists the items which are most relevant to us, and it will be easier to handle than the OWASP Top 10. I'll introduce the separate items, along with examples from our very own TOPdesk world. After the intitial introduction we'll start the discussion to see how we can make this list obsolete as quickly as possible.

events.title: Webcomponents: what should we build with them?
events.abstractText: The session would start off with a max 15 min presentation from Krisz. It includes going through the terminology real quick align concepts to the words we use for them. (Eg. what is a component, a pattern, webcomponent, the pattern library, the theme, an application team). During the talk we'll attempt to uncover what to expect from application team skills, how to approach being in a sprint where a new pattern/component is needed, and how to contribute to a shared benefit.

events.title: AI at TOPdesk - What does the future bring?
events.abstractText:
AI gives us a plethora of new possibilities in creating software. Think for example of improved language understanding, recognizing similar entities, classifying data, recognizing anomalies, or making predictions. We can think of these possibilities as our AI Toolkit. We start this workshop with a short introduction of the AI toolkit. Then, participants will split up in small groups and apply the toolkit to TOPdesk. They will identify how we can apply AI in the future to create a product that makes service desks more mature.

This workshop has two goals: 1) identify AI use cases for our AI roadmap, and 2) stimulate developers to think about possible applications of AI in their daily projects.

This workshop is hosted by dutch consultant Sylvie Bruys. It is not technical, and intended for all disciplines.

events.title: Accessibility race
events.abstractText: Experience TOPdesk in a whole new way! Win awesome prizes!

events.title: Programmer Alignment
events.abstractText:
In this highly interactive session we would like to reach a consensus on a set of guidelines for Programmers regarding code quality in both TOS and services. We want programmers to be aligned in knowing what to do and the organisation to support them in doing so. This session will tackle the first half, so we all agree on what to ask support for from the organisation.

Topics that we will discuss include: dependency management, automated tests, responsibilities, code quality. These are broad topics, but we will discuss specific questions in order to keep the session focused.

Extensive knowledge of the topics is not required. We'd rather have more programmers attending, such that the guidelines are widely supported, than having really in-depth nit-picky discussions between experts.

The format will be as follows: you will be seated in small groups (4-6 persons). We pose a statement and introduce it. You'll then spend a couple of minutes forming an opinion within your group. Then we gather the opinion of all groups. If there is consensus, we directly form it into a guideline. If more discussion is needed, then we'll appoint representatives of the different stances. These representatives are then expected to continue the discussion at another time and settle on a guideline.

The guidelines that stem from this session will be the law!

events.title: How to make the IDMx better
events.abstractText: It seems like several developers are unhappy with the format of the IDMx and therefore prefer not to attend. If you count yourselves as one of these, please join this session. We are interested in your direct feedback but mostly in your wishes and ideas to improve the IDMx in the future to make it appealing for you.

events.title: Product Cells, how to evolve
events.abstractText:
Mark, Harmen, and Cees have been working on the future setup of the product development department. You may have read or heard about this concept under the flag ‘Product cells’. Since the beginning, the aim was to have small sessions where groups of around 15 people had the possibility to hear about the concept and work together with us to find out how this could take form.

We would like to use this moment on the IDM to give you a short update on the concept, the steps we took so far, and the challenges ahead. The presentation part will be small, just to get everybody on the same page. Our aim for this session is to put its weight into having valuable conversations and spend some time together to work on the concept.

events.title: Future Incident Concept
events.abstractText:
In this session we want to have a look at the Incident card and our Incident concept. We want to analyse the current incident card step by step and try to understand on which concepts it is based. Then we brainstorm different incident concepts with the needs of our current customers and target group in mind.

Is the concept too complex?

Should we get rid of certain functionality?

Is our current concept multiple concepts combined?

events.title: Courage - Why do things that you actually don't dare?
events.abstractText:
Courage is needed when you decide to do something and you are not sure what the outcome will be. Or in my own interpretation: doing something that you actually don't really dare to do. You take a risk, and this unknown can result in success or failure. Also at work, courage should be highly appreciated; for people taking a step, but also for colleagues that have a role in supporting them, in good and in bad.

Personally, I'm not the brave type. But looking back, in work and in life, I did not always take the easy road and did do stuff that surprised myself and others. I dived a bit into this, and the concept of courage in general. By telling my personal story to you, I hope to inspire you to maybe do that scary thing that's already bothering you for a while, or to jump into future challenges that will come on your path.

events.title: Debunking the US vs THEM paradigm - seeing beyond branches
events.abstractText:
The Dutch always discuss too much!’ ‘Why are the Germans so rude?’ ‘You never know what the Hungarians are doing!’ It’s easy to see your foreign colleagues not as individuals but as an amorphous ‘them’.

Not only does this lead to less than perfect collaboration but you also miss out on so many potential wonderful friendships!

In this interactive session we want to share our personal experiences in order to help you with getting to know one another to hopefully become better colleagues and friends!

Simply bring your open mind and let us grow together!

events.title: Presentation patterns - and anti patterns?
events.abstractText:
Presentation patterns provide a common language to talk about dos and don’ts during presentations. Using fun examples I’ll highlight some of the common patterns and anti-patterns I notice during IDMx sessions, conferences and other presentations. Have you ever created “Slideuments”? Do you like to go “Meta”? Do you long for a “Brain break”? All while “Defying Defaults”? Attending this session will show you how this jibberish will improve your public speaking skills.

This presentation is based on the book “Presentation patterns” by Ford, McCullough and Schutta. The Pattern and anti-pattern concept resonates so well with developers that I’d love to introduce it within TOPdesk to enable better feedback on presentations. And better presentations overall!

events.title: Knowledge Management in Development
events.abstractText: The number of tools, technologies, and frameworks used in and for TOPdesk development has increased massively with the introduction of the service architecture. Though the knowledge how to use and work with these technologies is scattered across our communication platforms and often shared only in "oral tradition". In this workshop, we want to collect opinions on this topic and ideas how to improve.

events.title: TOPdesk 2023
events.abstractText: During this interactive session we’ll dive into the future, to explore what TOPdesk will/could be in 2023. Why will future customers choose us over our competitors? How can we embrace new technologies to wow our customers? And more… Bring your own ideas and help us envision the future.

events.title: Security Pub Quiz
events.abstractText:
Are you up for some fun? Want to show your colleagues how much you know about all kinds of useful and totally useless trivia? Join us for an intense but unforgettable hour of pub quizzing.

The first beer will be on us. Create your winning team (3-6p), but note that forming a team with participants from multiple branches earns you bonus points. The winning team will receive a proverbial beer shower, as well as the obligatory eternal fame!

This year the organization of the pub quiz is in the hands of a professional pub quiz master: KaiD
